item.title: New Linux malware combines unusual stealth with a full suite of capabilities

item.title: Unforgiveable C programming – keeping simple
item.description: As many people never tire of explaining, the C language is obsolete, unsafe, unwelcome in polite company and generally looked down on  by thought leaders and adepts of λ calculus .  Here’s a program that exhibits the lamentably low level nature of  C as it changes the call stack on x86-64 so that it calls “one” and prints out “one returns 1” and then mysteriously prints “one does not return 1”.
item.author: (vy)

item.title: learning about zero-knowledge apps and circuits using the noname educational DSL
item.description:
I've talked about noname previously, my toy side project to create a DSL to write zkapps on top of kimchi. I've recorded a video that showcase it, and walks through the circuit output by compiling one of the example. It might not make too much sense if you don't know about kimchi or plonk. And so you might want to watch my series of videos on plonk beforehands.
you can play with the noname langua ...

item.title: Cultivating serendipity
item.description: The discovery of penicillin and X-rays; Newton and the apple; Archimedes in the bath. So often, it seems, someone trying their best to work out a difficult problem ends up stumbling onto the solution by accident. But do you have to leave everything up to chance? Or can you organise your life in a way that maximises the chances of these unintended benefits?
item.author: (Rob Miller)
